SENT.plain: A 60-year old man with familial antithrombin III deficiency, a primary cause of hypercoagulation, developed central retinal vein occlusion
Familial antithrombin III deficiency is inherited as an autosomal dominant condition
It is characterized by recurrent episodes of thromboembolism
The occurrence of central retinal vein occlusion in a person with familial deficiency of antithrombin III suggests the possibility of a casual relationship
